updateNotes: UPDATED: Added Johns Hopkins 401k loans. Corrected Navy Federal MMI rates to 9.9%. Recalculated all strategies with new debt totals.

reasoning: User's $500/month extra payment capacity is LIMITED - must maximize every dollar
6 promotional balances ($5,739.61) with $1,972.22 deferred interest at risk - defending these saves massive interest penalties
After promos cleared (May 2026), avalanche order targets bleeding debts: SoFi 17.89% ($606.78/month interest), Amex 28.74%, Capital One 27.99-28.74%
User preference for 'quick wins' satisfied by eliminating 6 promotional debts in first 6 months
Mathematically optimal: Saves $1,972.22 in deferred interest PLUS minimizes ongoing interest on high-APR debts
Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 at 8.50% should be accelerated after SoFi eliminated - higher than most MMI debts and frees $828.53/month
MMI program ($1,751/month) is LOCKED - cannot modify without exiting program, so extra $500 must target non-MMI debts strategically
detailedSequence: Phase 1 (Dec 2025 - Jan 2026): Eliminate PayPal promos expiring 01/11/26 ($544.84) - Save $66.11
Phase 3 (Feb-Mar 2026): Eliminate PayPal promo expiring 02/11/26 ($372.00) - Save $40.67
Phase 4 (Mar-May 2026): Eliminate Container Store promo ($2,323.15) - Save $1,766.89
Phase 5 (May 2026): Eliminate Ashley PayPal promo ($751.62) - Save $23.23
Phase 6 (Jun 2026+): AVALANCHE ORDER - Attack SoFi 17.89%, then Amex 28.74%, then Capital One 27.99-28.74%, then Navy Federal 16.3%, then Aven 13.49%, then Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 @ 8.50%
MMI Debts: Continue $1,751/month as committed until program completion (2029-2031)
Mortgages: Pay minimums only ($5,135.57/month) - revisit after unsecured debts eliminated

hybrid_avalanche_promos_first.description: Defend promotional deadlines FIRST to save $1,972.22, then attack highest APR debts in avalanche order. Mathematically optimal + psychologically smart.

phase1_promotional_defense.cashFlowFreedPhase1: Promotional minimums no longer required after May 2026

phase2_avalanche_attack.description: After promotional debts cleared, attack non-MMI unsecured debts in strict APR order (highest first)
payoffOrder: 6. SoFi Personal Loan ($40,735.15 @ 17.89%) - Aug 2029 MAJOR MILESTONE - Frees $1,042.78/month!
7. Navy Federal CC ***561145 ($4,431.10 @ 16.3% MMI) - Consider extra payments after SoFi
9. Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 ($35,360.58 @ 8.50%) - Aug 2033 - Frees $828.53/month for retirement!
10. SPS Mortgage ($167,717.79 @ 8.375%) - MINIMUM ONLY unless refinance opportunity

13. Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 1 ($4,398.64 @ 4.25%) - Natural payoff Jan 2026
14. SBA EIDL ($58,711.87 @ 3.75%) - Minimum only, LAST priority (30-year term)

keyMilestones.event: PayPal Standard Balance eliminated - Last 30% APR debt gone
All Amex + Capital One cards eliminated - No more 28-29% APR debts
SoFi Personal Loan ELIMINATED - Frees $1,042.78/month, saves $606.78/month interest
Aven card eliminated - All 13%+ APR debts gone
Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 eliminated - Frees $828.53/month for retirement contributions
ALL UNSECURED DEBT ELIMINATED (except SBA EIDL minimum payments)

totalInterestPaid.note: Mortgages calculated at minimum payments for full term. Unsecured interest dramatically reduced by avalanche targeting.

debtFreeDate.note: SBA EIDL runs to maturity (2050). Mortgages run full term unless accelerated or refinanced.

pros: SAVES $1,972.22 by defending promotional deadlines - massive ROI on first 6 months
Mathematically optimal AFTER promos defended - minimizes total interest on ongoing debts
Attacks bleeding debts: SoFi 17.89% costing $606.78/month interest
Provides quick wins (7 accounts closed in first 6 months) for psychological motivation
Targets Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 at 8.50% appropriately - higher than most MMI debts
Frees significant monthly cash flow: SoFi payoff frees $1,042.78/month, 401k Loan 2 frees $828.53/month
Respects MMI commitment ($1,751/month locked) while optimizing $500 extra payments
Emergency fund building can happen in parallel (dedicate $50-100/month from extra capacity)
cons: Takes 8.3 years to eliminate unsecured debts (100 months) - long timeline
Large balances like SoFi ($40,735) take 3.5 years after promos cleared
Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 not paid off until Aug 2033 (missed retirement contributions)
Requires discipline to maintain strategy over 8+ years
SBA EIDL at $58,711 will take 25 years if only paying minimums

pure_avalanche.description: Strict APR order - highest to lowest, ignoring promotional deadlines. MATHEMATICAL ONLY - NOT RECOMMENDED.
pure_avalanche.criticalFlaw: IGNORES PROMOTIONAL DEADLINES - Would LOSE $1,972.22 in deferred interest penalties

totalInterestPaid.note: Pure avalanche COSTS $3,944.44 MORE than hybrid due to lost promotional deadlines + penalties

pros: Mathematically consistent - always targets highest APR
Simple to execute - no strategy switches
cons: LOSES $1,972.22 by missing promotional deadlines - DISQUALIFYING FLAW
First payoff is small ($375.04) - minimal motivation
No strategic flexibility for urgent situations
Actually COSTS MORE than hybrid approach

snowball.description: Pay debts in order of smallest to largest balance. Maximizes quick wins and psychological motivation.
snowball.criticalFlaw: Attacks SoFi 17.89% ($606.78/month interest bleed) LAST after many lower-rate debts. Maximizes total interest paid.

totalInterestPaid.note: Snowball COSTS $30,920.11 MORE in interest than hybrid avalanche approach

debtFreeDate.note: Takes 2.7 YEARS LONGER to eliminate unsecured debt vs hybrid (2036 vs 2034)

pros: MAXIMUM psychological wins - 10 accounts closed in first 18 months
Immediate motivation from seeing balances disappear
Defends most promotional deadlines by balance order
cons: COSTS $30,920.11 MORE in total interest vs hybrid avalanche
SoFi 17.89% bleeds $606.78/month interest for YEARS while paying low-rate debts
Takes 2.7 years longer to become debt-free (2036 vs 2034)
Attacks CHASE 3.2% ($14,503 + $21,703) before SoFi 17.89% ($40,735) - backwards math
User has LIMITED $500/month extra capacity - cannot afford to waste $30,920 on inefficient strategy
Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 at 8.50% attacked after low-rate MMI debts - delays retirement contributions
snowball.recommendationLevel: NOT RECOMMENDED - User cannot afford $30,920 interest penalty with limited extra payment capacity

consolidation.description: Evaluate consolidation loan options to potentially reduce APRs and simplify payments

eligible_debts: Non-MMI credit cards: $64,491.38 (Amex, Capital One, Aven, PayPal)
Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2: $35,360.58 (cannot consolidate - employer loan)
analysis.mmiDebts_notConsolidatable: $77,778.92 (locked in MMI program - cannot exit without penalties)
analysis.constraintMMI: MMI program requires $1,751/month commitment. Exiting MMI would lose negotiated rate reductions (saving $162/month) and could trigger penalties.
analysis.401kLoan_constraint: Johns Hopkins 401k Loan 2 cannot be consolidated - it's an employer loan tied to 401k account.
challenges: Credit score unknown - may not qualify for rates better than current SoFi 17.89%
High DTI of 45.7% may disqualify from new loans or result in high rates
MMI debts ($77,778.92) are locked - cannot consolidate without exiting program (not recommended)
Home equity line of credit (HELOC) could offer 8-9% rates but adds risk to primary residence
Balance transfer cards require good credit and have 3-5% fees - may not offer better net rate
Personal loan consolidation likely 12-16% APR range given debt load - may not save vs avalanche attack

scenario1_perfectCredit.likelihood: LOW - requires excellent credit (750+) and low DTI

scenario3_heloc.risksAdded: Secured by primary residence - foreclosure risk if unable to pay
scenario3_heloc.likelihood: POSSIBLE but HIGH RISK - not recommended with DTI 45.7%

analysis.recommendation: DO NOT PURSUE CONSOLIDATION at this time
reasoning: Credit score unknown - cannot assess qualification likelihood
High DTI (45.7%) likely disqualifies from favorable rates
MMI debts ($77,778.92) already at negotiated low rates (3.2%-16.3%, avg 6.87%) - cannot beat these rates
Hybrid avalanche strategy is GUARANTEED to work with current $500/month capacity
Consolidation adds complexity, potential fees (3-5%), and uncertain approval
Risk of trading unsecured debt for secured debt (HELOC) is unacceptable
Better strategy: Execute hybrid avalanche → Build credit → Revisit consolidation in 12-24 months after credit cards eliminated

consolidation.recommendationLevel: NOT RECOMMENDED NOW - Revisit after eliminating high-rate debts and building credit

timeToDebtFree_unsecured.consolidation_best_case: 96 months (8 years) - IF approved at 10% APR (unlikely)

strategyComparison.runnerUp: Pure Avalanche (but loses $3,944 to missed promotional deadlines)
notRecommended: Consolidation (unlikely to qualify for beneficial rates)

keySuccessFactors: DISCIPLINE: Stick to strategy for 8+ years despite setbacks
EMERGENCY FUND: Build $1,000 immediately, then $5,000, then $24,500 to protect against derailment
MMI COMMITMENT: Continue $1,751/month payments without fail to maintain negotiated rates
DEADLINE TRACKING: Use calendar alerts for promotional balances - cannot miss deadlines
WINDFALL ALLOCATION: Apply any bonuses, tax refunds, or extra income to debt per avalanche order
CASH FLOW VIGILANCE: Monitor DTI 45.7% carefully - any income disruption could create crisis
